text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 1.14.7, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program.

On October 1, 2014, Real Estate and Facilities Management (REFM) merged with Physical Security and Emergency Preparedness (PSEP) to create Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS). This IRM was updated to reﬂect editorial changes and changes to current organizational

As of January 1, 2017, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) is instituting a requirement that the IRM addresses relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and for internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the programs policies and procedures which ensure:

a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms deﬁned. b. Program goals are established and performance is measured to assess the efficient and effective mission and objective accomplishment. c. Program and resources are protected against waste, fraud, abuse, mismanagement and misappropriation. d. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. e. Financial reporting is complete, current and accurate. f. Reliable information is obtained and used for decision making and quality assurance. On October

, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed by Small Business/Self Employed (SB/SE) and FMSS, regarding Fleet Management. This IRM was updated to reﬂect program management changes agreed on in the MOU. The required Enterprise Learning Management System (ELMS) Defensive Driving course number was changed to
This IRM supersedes IRM 1.14.7, dated August 19, 2013.

Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program

) Purpose: This IRM provides directives, authorities and responsibilities for Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program. The program is used by all IRS Business Units (BU) that operate government-owned or leased motor as well as those employees who use personally-owned or rental vehicles official government business (

) Policy Owner: Chief, Facilities Management and Security Services (
) Program Owner: FMSS Chief, Environment, Health and Safety (EHS). (
) Primary Stakeholders: BU operating government owned/leased motor vehicles, FMSS Territory Managers (TM) and their personnel. (

) Purpose: This IRM provides directives, authorities and responsibilities for the Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program. The program is used by all IRS Business Units (BU) that operate government-owned or leased motor as well as those employees who use personally-owned or rental vehicles for official government business (

) Primary Stakeholders: BU operating government owned/leased motor vehicles, FMSS Territory Managers (TM) and their personnel. (

, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program, provides purpose, au- thorities, directives, and responsibilities for the Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program. The program is used by all IRS BU that operate government-owned or leased motor vehicles, as well as those with employees who use personally-owned or rental vehicles for official government business. The FMSS organization manages a motor pool ﬂeet for BU across IRS. FMSS assigns a ﬂeet program manager at the Headquarters (HQ) level

Points of Contact (POC) for the BU using motor vehicles, as well external stakeholders. Criminal Investigation (CI) BU manages a separate ﬂeet for their employees and assigns their own ﬂeet program managers.

For additional law enforcement ﬂeet guidance, see CI IRM 9.1.4, Criminal Investigation Mission and Strategies, Criminal Investigation Directives and Functional Delegations of Authority and IRM 9.11.3, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, INVESTIGATIVE PROPERTY.

An IRS BU that operates motor vehicles must: a. Manage the vehicles in the organizational unit, including assigning vehicles and ﬂeet credit cards, marshaling and arranging for vehicle pre- ventive maintenance, repairs and recall work. Each BU must ensure that employees operating government-leased/owned vehicles are properly licensed to do so. b. Follow instructions in IRM

, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program, policies and directives issued by the ﬂeet program managers, and General Services Administration (GSA) bulletins concerning ﬂeet op- erations. Ensure that prior to taking possession of a vehicle, all motor vehicle operators read and comply with the requirements of this IRM. c. Maintain and timely submit appropriate paperwork including: mileage/ usage logs and home-to-work logs for each vehicle showing dates, mileage, and destination for each trip. d. Submit vehicle mileage/usage logs and home-to-work logs to the local FMSS motor vehicle coordinator or ﬂeet program manager monthly. e. Retain vehicle mileage/usage logs and home-to-work logs for a period of two years after the date of disposal of the vehicle. These logs must be complete, legible, and available for inspection by appropriate officials when requested. f. Implement all federal regulations, TD and IRS directives, procedures, guidelines that apply to the administration of the IRS Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program. g. Determine and report current and future requirements for motor vehicles, related facilities, and accessory equipment to the local FMSS motor vehicle coordinator for vehicles in the FMSS-managed motor pool ﬂeet the ﬂeet program manager for vehicles in the CI ﬂeet. Note: For additional law enforcement ﬂeet guidance, see CI IRM
, Criminal Investigation Mission and Strategies, Criminal Directives and Functional Delegations of Authority and IRM

, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, INVESTIGATIVE PROPERTY. h. Provide funds and facilities for maintaining, storing, parking, and operating IRS motor vehicles (including law enforcement vehicles), and for obtaining related supplies, services, and accessories. i. Formulate maintenance, repair, and storage procedures for IRS-owned law enforcement vehicles and related equipment, as required. j. Submit all information regarding vehicles to the appropriate personnel for entry into the Knowledge, Incident/Problem, Service Asset Management (KISAM) or Criminal Investigation Management Inventory System (CIMIS), within
days of acquisition, transfer, when disposal procedures are initiated, and at ﬁnal disposition.

For additional law enforcement ﬂeet guidance, see CI IRM 9.1.4, Criminal Investigation Mission and Strategies, Criminal Investigation Directives and Functional Delegations of Authority and IRM 9.11.3, Fiscal and Personnel Matters, INVESTIGATIVE PROPERTY.

Provide funds and facilities for maintaining, storing, parking, and operating IRS motor vehicles (including law enforcement vehicles), and for obtaining related supplies, services, and accessories. Formulate maintenance, repair, and storage procedures for IRS-owned law enforcement vehicles and related equipment, as required. Submit all information regarding vehicles to the appropriate personnel for entry into the Knowledge, Incident/Problem, Service Asset Management (KISAM) or Criminal Investigation Management Inventory System (CIMIS), within
days of acquisition, transfer, when disposal procedures are initiated, and at ﬁnal disposition.
Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program

k. Devise, perform, and/or direct feasibility studies of motor vehicle use in their functions to ensure their employees and the IRS are provided the best possible transportation at the least cost to the government. l. Implement the procedures and methods contained in IRM

, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program, covering the acquisition of vehicles through transfer, forfeiture, seizure, exchange/sale, and disposition of motive equipment. m. Comply with the IRS requirements under the Energy Policy Act of
, Clean Air Act, Energy Independence and Security Act of
, relevant Executive Orders, and other federal, state, and local regulations as they apply to motor vehicles.

) IRS only authorizes employees to use government vehicles for official purposes (i.e., official use) to perform the mission of the IRS, which transportation: a. Between places of official business. b. As otherwise authorized by the approving official. (

) Examples of official business include an employee’s transportation: a. To a taxpayer’s home or office. b. To locate witnesses. c. To courthouses and land record offices. d. Between IRS Posts of Duty (POD). e. To any other location where employees would be required to go in performance of official duties. Note: Employees may stop to purchase meals or other items necessary for welfare, or sustenance, as long as these stops are along a
IRM 1.2.18.1.2 Policy Statement 9-85, Luxury class vehicles excluded from motor vehicle ﬂeet except for surveillance or undercover work

) IRS only authorizes employees to use government vehicles for official purposes (i.e., official use) to perform the mission of the IRS, which transportation: a. Between places of official business. b. As otherwise authorized by the approving official. (

) Examples of official business include an employee’s transportation: a. To a taxpayer’s home or office. b. To locate witnesses. c. To courthouses and land record offices. d. Between IRS Posts of Duty (POD). e. To any other location where employees would be required to go in the performance of official duties. Note: Employees may stop to purchase meals or other items necessary for welfare, or sustenance, as long as these stops are along a route and are without interference to their official business. (

) IRS employees may also use government vehicles for transportation when travel status to obtain meals, lodging, and to travel between place of and place or area of employment and/or railroad, airport, and other so authorized. (

) IRS employees in travel status may be permitted to use a government to return to their home or POD at the end of a workweek before traveling to the same or different temporary duty station the following week. However, travel is governed by IRM
, Official IRS City to City Travel Guide. (

) Transportation of the following categories of passengers is authorized their presence contributes to the performance of official government a. Federal, state, and local officials, b. Accredited representatives of foreign governments, c. Private citizens providing official assistance, d. Contractors performing official business for the government, e. Any person deemed essential to the completion of the mission.
(09-27-2018) Use of Government Motor Vehicles
Transportation of the following categories of passengers is authorized when their presence contributes to the performance of official government business:
Note: All contractors performing official duties for the government must have a tiﬁcate of liability available. (

) Enforcement vehicles are assigned to enforcement personnel in CI as a re- quirement to conduct enforcement duties. These duties include surveillance, intelligence gathering, arrests and raids, transportation of prisoners, and activities normally expected of an enforcement assignment. (
) IRM
, Official IRS Local Travel Guide and IRM
, Official IRS to-City Travel Guide, provide IRS policies for using government and vehicles during official travel. (

) Unauthorized use of a government vehicle includes transporting personnel: a. in excess of its normal capacity. of b. for the performance of personal business. c. to any religious, sport, amusement, or recreational activity, except on official business. d. on authorized leave while in travel status, except as necessary and thorized to travel in route to or from temporary POD and residence or official duty station. (

) Unauthorized use also includes operating or parking a government vehicle violation of any federal, state, or municipal regulation. Drivers must operate vehicles in accordance with the laws of the local jurisdiction. (
) The IRS handles disciplinary action for unauthorized use in accordance with provisions of
USC, Section
, and IRM
, Discipline and for ary Actions: Policies, Responsibilities, Authorities, and Guidance, which of speciﬁes a minimum suspension of at least
days for anyone who uses authorizes the use of a motor vehicle for other than official purposes. Also to IRS Document
, Guide to Penalty Determinations. (

) An employee’s immediate supervisor will report possible unauthorized use, presence of unauthorized persons in a vehicle, or personal misconduct to Office of the Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA). (

) IRS employees may use a government owned or leased vehicle for tion from place of employment to domicile and/or from domicile to place of employment only when such use has been authorized consistent with of USC
and TD
, Home-to-Work Transportation. (
) The
USC Section

permits home-to-work transportation for the Use) Secretary of the Treasury and for other employees when the Secretary rizes the use of home-to-work transportation. The Secretary is the only within the Department of the Treasury who may make a determination that thorizes the use of government vehicles for home-to-work transportation for employees. Prior approval is required. (
) TD
, Home-to-Work Transportation Controls, prescribes home-to-work authorizations for IRS employees.
Unauthorized use of a government vehicle includes transporting personnel:
Fleet Management Program

) Use of a motor vehicle between an IRS employee’s residence and place of employment qualiﬁes as transportation for an official purpose only when the Secretary of the Treasury determines that: a. transportation between residence and various locations is required for performance of ﬁeld work, in accordance with applicable regulations. These determinations will be for a maximum of two years or as deter- mined by the Secretary. b. transportation between residence and various locations is essential for safe and efficient performance of intelligence, counterintelligence, tive services, or criminal law enforcement duties. These will be for a maximum of two years or as determined by the Secretary. c. highly unusual circumstances, a clear and present danger, an or other compelling operational considerations make this type of work transportation essential to conduct official business. These determinations are effective for not more than
calendar days, able for two
day periods at the discretion of the Secretary. (
) Commuting miles between the employee’s residence and official duty will not exceed
miles one way unless an exception is approved by the Secretary. Use of the home-to-work vehicle to commute will not exceed
percent of the total usage of the vehicle during the ﬁscal year. (

) Home-to-work transportation will only be authorized when such use will sub- stantially increase the economy and efficiency of the government, and will be authorized solely or principally for the comfort or convenience of the employee. Home-to-work transportation will be authorized only to complete those tasks necessary for the accomplishment of the IRS mission, and not thorized solely for the comfort or convenience of the employee. (
) Home-to-work authorizations will not be based on the grade or position of employee. (
) Transit subsidies and other transit/parking beneﬁts will be adjusted to take account the use of home-to-work transportation. (

) The IRS will acquire vehicles for home-to-work use that are the most fuel efficient and lowest Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emitting necessary to execute mission requirements. The IRS will place Alternative Fuel Vehicles (AFV) where the appropriate alternative fuel is available. Home-to-work vehicles be incorporated into the IRS vehicle allocation methodology. (

) The IRS may only provide an employee with home-to-work transportation a determination has been executed by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Commissioner will determine which employees may be eligible to use work transportation and will submit requests for determinations and memorandum format to the office of the Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Office of Asset Management (OAM). (

) Each memorandum will: a. explain the basis for the request. (i.e., include facts and circumstances that clearly demonstrate how the relevant statutory standard is met how the use of a government vehicle will substantially increase the ciency and economy or how it is essential to the conduct of business) Internal Revenue Manual

b. describe the types and numbers of employees who will be authorized use the motor vehicles as well as the situations in which they will be used. c. describe how the bureau will conduct and document adequate training least annually to home-to-work transportation employees on home-to- work transportation and applicable requirements for use of a vehicle. d. describe the reviews and administrative controls which will be relied mitigate risk of unauthorized use, abuse, loss, and theft of the and verify that home-to-work transportation is used solely for the for which it is intended. e. identify speciﬁc individuals to be responsible for conducting the and emphasizing compliance with administrative controls. f. provide a written statement of assurance that the requested determinations are necessary to the IRS mission requirements and applicable statutes and regulations. This statement will include an tive statement that the necessary funding is approved and available to cover the costs required for the timeframe requested for home-to-work transportation. Execution of this statement of assurance cannot be delegated. (

) Each request will also provide a detailed business case, including but not limited to: a. a cost-beneﬁt analysis for using home-to-work transportation. b. a justiﬁcation that assesses the relative importance to the agency’s mission of authorizing home to work. c. an explanation of why it is critical to the IRS mission that performance duties begins at an employee’s residence rather than official duty if applicable. d. examination of the record to determine the frequency with which response from home has been required, if applicable. (
) Home-to-work determinations must be submitted for the Secretary’s review later than
days prior to expiration. (

) IRS functions with employees authorized for home-to-work transportation prepare, implement, and monitor a home-to-work transportation and Internal Controls and Compliance (MICC) plan. The documentation to the plan will be made available for periodic review by DCFO and OAM (

) The IRS function must maintain a list of active home-to-work transportation employees detailing: a. Name and title of the employee b. Vehicle information c. Dates that home-to-work transportation is authorized, including date and expiration date d. Location of residence, including distance between the residence and station e. Type of home-to-work determination (

Fleet Management Program

) Employees using government-owned or leased vehicles for home-to-work transportation must maintain a vehicle usage log, including home-to-work transportation mileage, other mileage, fuel use, and maintenance. The IRS function to which the vehicle is assigned will retain the vehicle usage logs make them available for review by the Department of the Treasury, GSA, or others as appropriate and necessary. (
) The appropriate IRS function will submit authorized home-to-work tion reports quarterly to DCFO, OAM on each vehicle. The reports will operational and commuting miles. (
) The provision of home-to-work transportation to an employee may result in “fringe beneﬁt income” to the employee. IRS BU will track and report the taxable fringe beneﬁts as appropriate. (

) Employees with home-to-work authorization will receive training on home-to- work transportation awareness and compliance with federal laws and regulations and sign a home-to-work certiﬁcation annually. These will be maintained by the appropriate IRS function. (
) All IRS-owned or leased vehicles must use official US government tags exempted. (

) Official US government tags cannot be transferred to another IRS vehicle. IRS may not sell or dispose of a vehicle without removing the tag. If a tag is lost, mutilated (needing replacement), or destroyed, the IRS BU using the vehicle must submit a written report to the FMSS motor vehicle or ﬂeet program manager regarding the incident. (

) GSA will grant unlimited exemptions from the requirement to display official government tags, shields, and other identiﬁcation to IRS motor vehicles operated in the performance of investigative, law enforcement, or duties. GSA may provide interagency ﬂeet vehicles to the IRS without signs identifying media when the vehicles are to be used for those purposes. (

) The Secretary of the Treasury or designee may authorize a limited from the requirement to display US government license plates and other ﬁcation on IRS-owned or leased motor vehicles. The exemption must state identifying the motor vehicle would endanger the security of the vehicle occupants or otherwise compromise the IRS mission. The limited exemption may last from one day up to three years. If the requirement for exemption exists beyond three years, the Department of the Treasury must re-certify continued exemption. The IRS Commissioner or Deputy Commissioner must sign all requests for limited exemptions for IRS vehicles (

) IRS owned or commercially leased vehicles exempted from identiﬁcation re- quirements must be registered and inspected in accordance with the laws of the state, commonwealth, or US territory where they operate. (

) An IRS BU acquiring IRS owned or commercially leased vehicles, other those exempted for use within the District of Columbia, must contact FMSS motor vehicle coordinator for registration and inspection information.
Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program

) Motor vehicles owned or leased by the government must pass federally mandated emissions inspections in the jurisdictions in which they operate, Inspection when required by state motor vehicle or environmental departments. Unless the fees are waived, IRS must reimburse the state activity for the cost of inspections. (

) Motor vehicles owned or leased by the government, whether they display ernment tags and identiﬁcation or are exempted from displaying them, must comply with emission and mechanical inspection requirements of the state, commonwealth, US territory, or the District of Columbia where they operate. (

) FMSS maintains a centralized record of vehicles in KISAM-Asset Manager (AM) for the FMSS managed ﬂeet. CI maintains records of its vehicles in CIMIS. These records describe the motor vehicle, the tag number, the Identiﬁcation Number (VIN), and the storage location of each vehicle. (

) Offices may optionally equip government-owned and leased vehicles with safety ﬂares, tire inﬂators, ﬁrst aid kits, antennas, mobile two-way radios Equipment other equipment deemed necessary for vehicle and operator safety. GSA mission is required. The IRS must remove any additional equipment or accessories before disposing of the vehicle. The IRS is responsible for of damage to the vehicle resulting from the installation and removal of equipment (
) The GSA provides a ﬂeet services credit card for all IRS vehicles. (
) Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR)

authorizes the Vehicle Credit Card commercial ﬂeet service credit card for the purchase of fuel, maintenance repair of government-owned or leased vehicles. Authorized transactions include: a. purchase of regular unleaded gasoline, diesel fuel, or alternative fuel from service stations offering the lowest price. Note: Purchase of premium fuel is not authorized unless the vehicle requires it. b. maintenance under $
without prior approval including the purchase oil changes, ﬂuids, wiper blades, car washes, and other necessary tenance and repair. c. maintenance over $
, the purchase of tires and batteries, and body

a. purchase of regular unleaded gasoline, diesel fuel, or alternative from service stations offering the lowest price. Note: Purchase of premium fuel is not authorized unless the vehicle requires it. b. maintenance under $
without prior approval including the oil changes, ﬂuids, wiper blades, car washes, and other necessary tenance and repair. c. maintenance over $
, the purchase of tires and batteries, and work requires prior approval from GSA Fleet at

Fleet credit cards cannot be used for: a. expenses for a personal vehicle while on government business. b. payment of toll charges, ﬁnes, or registration fees. c. storage fees. d. purchase of food, beverages, or other items for personal use. Each operator of a government-owned or leased motor vehicle or owned vehicle used for official business must be furnished a copy of IRM
, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program, by their manager and operate the vehicle accordingly. In addition, each driver should review the document, Guide to Your Fleet Vehicle.
maintenance over $100, the purchase of tires and batteries, and body work requires prior approval from GSA Fleet at 1(866) 400-0411.
Each operator of a government-owned or leased motor vehicle or privately- owned vehicle used for official business must be furnished a copy of IRM
, Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program, by their manager and operate the vehicle accordingly. In addition, each driver should review the document, Guide to Your Fleet Vehicle.
Motor Vehicle Fleet Management Program

) Any employee using a government-owned, leased, or rental vehicle is sible for exercising reasonable diligence in the care of the vehicle and its contents, including: a. Reviewing the proper procedures in operating the vehicle. b. Driving defensively and safely obeying all federal, state and local laws and regulations. c. Safeguarding the vehicle, ﬂeet credit card, keys, and any government property contained within the vehicle against damage, theft, or misuse. d. Reporting lost, damaged, or stolen license plates and/or ﬂeet credit immediately to their manager and their motor vehicle coordinator. e. Carrying a valid operator’s license at all times. f. Using seat belts when operating or when a passenger of a owned or leased vehicle. g. Completing the vehicle mileage/usage log legibly for each trip. h. Not smoking in the vehicle. i. Using alternative fuel (E-
) when available in AFV in compliance with Executive Order
Law enforcement vehicle operators should use alternative fuel to the maximum extent possible. (
) Managers must ascertain that employees under their supervision who motor vehicles for official purposes are properly licensed. (

) Federal employees who operate a government owned or leased vehicle, or privately-owned motor vehicle for the IRS, are required to: a. possess valid state/international licenses for the class of vehicle they operate. Employees must notify their manager if their driver’s license suspended, revoked, canceled, or they have been otherwise from holding licenses. b. receive manager’s approval to operate the vehicle. c. be at least

years old. d. have their driving records validated by the state and/or national driver register upon employment and whenever management deems it advisable to review. International-licensed drivers are exempt. This dation is delegated to local managers and supervisors and may be delegated down, as deemed appropriate. (
) In the event the employee’s driver’s license is suspended or revoked, they must notify the manager immediately no later than
days from the notice suspension or revocation. (
) Employees who operate a government-owned or leased vehicle are self certify on the vehicle usage log that they have a valid driver’s license the class of vehicle they operate. (
) Employees are strongly discouraged from the use of hand-held wireless devices while operating motor vehicles on official business. and (

) Vehicle operators are responsible for accident prevention and must obey all motor vehicle traffic laws of the state and local jurisdiction, including those governing the use of seat belts and the use of wireless devices while except when the duties of their position require otherwise. Internal Revenue Manual
Any employee using a government-owned, leased, or rental vehicle is respon- sible for exercising reasonable diligence in the care of the vehicle and its contents, including:

Reviewing the proper procedures in operating the vehicle. Driving defensively and safely obeying all federal, state and local traffic laws and regulations. Safeguarding the vehicle, ﬂeet credit card, keys, and any government property contained within the vehicle against damage, theft, or misuse. Reporting lost, damaged, or stolen license plates and/or ﬂeet credit immediately to their manager and their motor vehicle coordinator. Carrying a valid operator’s license at all times. Using seat belts when operating or when a passenger of a government- owned or leased vehicle. Completing the vehicle mileage/usage log legibly for each trip. Not smoking in the vehicle. Using alternative fuel (E-
) when available in AFV in compliance with Executive Order
Law enforcement vehicle operators should use alternative fuel to the maximum extent possible.
1.14.7.2.7 (09-27-2018) Operator Licensing
Managers must ascertain that employees under their supervision who operate motor vehicles for official purposes are properly licensed.
Federal employees who operate a government owned or leased vehicle, or privately-owned motor vehicle for the IRS, are required to:

possess valid state/international licenses for the class of vehicle they operate. Employees must notify their manager if their driver’s license is suspended, revoked, canceled, or they have been otherwise disqualiﬁed from holding licenses. receive manager’s approval to operate the vehicle. be at least

years old. have their driving records validated by the state and/or national driver register upon employment and whenever management deems it advisable to review. International-licensed drivers are exempt. This vali- dation is delegated to local managers and supervisors and may be delegated down, as deemed appropriate.
Employees are strongly discouraged from the use of hand-held wireless devices while operating motor vehicles on official business.
) EO

, Federal Leadership on Reducing Text Messaging While bans federal employees who are operating motor vehicles from text when: a. driving a government owned or leased vehicle. b. driving a personal vehicle on official government business. (
) Federal employees are prohibited from driving any vehicle (personal or ment) when using electronic equipment supplied by the government Blackberry). (
) As deﬁned by EO

, ″driving″ means operating a motor vehicle on active roadway with the motor running, including while temporarily because of traffic, a traffic light or stop sign, or otherwise. It does not operating a motor vehicle with or without the motor running when one pulled over to the side, or off an active roadway and has halted in a where one can safely remain stationary. (
) As deﬁned by EO

, texting includes reading from or entering data any handheld or other electronic device for the purpose of text emailing, obtaining navigational information, or engaging in any other electronic data retrieval or communication. The IRS does not consider following actions texting for the purposes of IRM

If an employee is involved in an accident while in a government-owned or leased vehicle, or in a privately-owned vehicle while on official government business, the employee must: a. take steps to prevent another accident. b. call for emergency services, if necessary. c. contact their manager or manager’s designee and OS Ge

ervices the accident immediately. d. obtain the facts (registration, insurance, witnesses), but not provide personal auto insurance information. Report that they are a federal employee, driving for their employer and that the federal government self-insured. e. not sign or make a statement as to responsibility or fault for the f. ask any witnesses to complete Standard Form (SF)-
, Statement of Witness. g. obtain a copy of the police report. h. complete SF-

from witnesses to the FMSS motor vehicle coordinator or appropriate ﬂeet manager and the local safety officer within

) Employees using vehicles for official business, whether leased, rented, privately or government owned, marked or unmarked, are subject to all Parking of nances such as restricted zones, no parking zones, and double-parking Motor restrictions. Violation of a parking ordinance generally is the personal bility of the driver of the vehicle. The IRS will request a local jurisdiction to rescind or cancel a citation, only in those situations where compelling exist, and the employee furnishes a justiﬁcation. In these cases, the local FMSS territory manager or appropriate ﬂeet manager will sign the written request. (

) IRS is responsible for the cost of any IRS-owned or leased vehicle stored other than a designated storage point. Assigned parking in a federal building or other space occupied by b. Street parking or other free parking within a reasonable distance from place where duty is performed; c. ) Use of Government or Personally-Owned Vehicles – The GSA, to the extent their capabilities, provides user agencies with motor vehicles for travel. The IRS will provide GSA vehicles, to the extent they are available, for its employees who require vehicles for official purposes. IRM
, Service- wide Financial Policies & Procedures, Official IRS Local Travel Guide and

, Servicewide Financial Policies and Procedures, Official IRS City-to- City Travel Guide contain criteria for use of government vehicles and owned vehicles, as well as determining reimbursement rates for use of a privately-owned vehicle on official business. (

) The IRS ﬂeets managed by FMSS lease vehicles from the GSA Interagency Fleet Management System motor pool: Motor Pool a. Based on GSA mileage requirements, IRS assigns GSA vehicles in priority order from highest mileage vehicles to those driven a minimum
miles per year in metropolitan areas or

miles per year in rural areas. The IRS does not normally assign GSA vehicles when the total annual mileage is less, except in unusual circumstances where no other options exist to meet transportation needs. Offices using vehicles for occasional travel and not meeting the mileage requirements must consider “pool” use of GSA vehicles. b. All vehicles in the FMSS-managed vehicles, except Fuel Compliance pick-up trucks, are required to be “pool” use (assigned to one or more IRS offices rather than a speciﬁc employee). If pool use of a speciﬁed vehicle in the FMSS-managed ﬂeet is not practical due to installed equipment or speciﬁc usage requirements, the IRS office using the vehicle must provide a written explanation of the need for excluding the vehicle from the program rotation requirements to the FMSS motor vehicle coordinator. (
) EO

, Relations Relating to the Establishment and Operation of Inter- agency Motor-Vehicle Pools and Systems, exempts any motor vehicle used by an agency in the performance of investigative law enforcement or in- telligence duties from inclusion in interagency motor vehicle pools. This exemption is available if the head of the agency determines that exclusive control of such vehicles is essential to the effective performance of such duties. The Department of the Treasury has determined that motor vehicles operated by Criminal Investigation division, Special Agents, meet the EO
conditions. (

) Passenger carrying vehicles – The IRS has set the following standards for accepting seized passenger vehicles in the IRS enforcement ﬂeet based on study, analysis, and experience of use of seized vehicles: a. Age - The current and three preceding model years b. Mileage - Not exceeding
c. Make – Any make and model, except those covered in IRM
, Policy Statement

, Luxury class vehicles excluded from motor ﬂeet except for surveillance or undercover work, for replacement of inferior vehicles as operations necessitate, to the extent they do not exceed the current ﬂeet allocation. d. Body - Sedans, station wagons, hatchbacks, vans, SUV and light-duty trucks e. Requirements and dollar limits - Before acquisition, each vehicle must subject to a safety, mechanical, and body inspection by a competent mechanic and a written estimate obtained of the cost to bring the into ﬂeet operable condition. No seized vehicle will be acquired where cost estimate to put into service exceeds
% of the vehicle’s current appraised value. f. Fuel economy - Preference is given to vehicles with better fuel and vehicles that use renewable energy or are hybrids. (

) Exception to Standards - Any seized passenger vehicle which does not the preceding standards and is desired for use in the IRS enforcement ﬂeet because of condition, color, make, or other characteristic, may be applied for and acquired if approved by CI in accordance with applicable delegation orders. (
) Seized Truck Standards - CI will apply national standards to determine what conditions to acquire seized and forfeited trucks. (
) Motorcycles – The IRS will not bring motorcycles into the enforcement ﬂeet. (

) An “enforcement type” vehicle is a standard vehicle equipped with certain features and accessories so that the vehicle will not be readily recognizable a government-owned vehicle. It will be equipped with certain extra features provide maximum safety to the driver and the public and with equipment to ensure speed, stamina, and durability to perform under adverse driving tions. This is not the “police-type vehicle” usually identiﬁed with police work. (
) In accordance with the Energy Policy Act (EPAct) of

, IRS will acquire AFV unless no infrastructure is available in the area where a vehicle will be located. Drivers must use alternative fuel in all AFV unless the IRS obtains a Department of Energy (DOE) waiver, as required by EPAct
Section Where applicable and to the maximum extent possible, law enforcement vehicles will conform to the preceding provisions. (
) The IRS will not place hybrid vehicles in locations where alternative fuel structure is available to support AFV. (

) The use of Plug-in Hybrid (PIH) vehicles will be required by all federal agencies when they become commercially available at a cost reasonably parable to non-PIH vehicles, on the basis of life-cycle cost. Internal Revenue Manual

and to comply with the energy conservation, minimum fuel efficiency, alternative use, and GHG emission reduction standards, all Treasury bureaus the IRS must: a. Purchases
the book value of a vehicle purchased new is its cost as shown on the purchase order and invoice, which included transportation costs to the ﬁrst delivery destination. Other acquisitions
the book value of all other vehicles acquired by IRS must be the appraised value, as indicated in the acquisition document.

While carrier damage is not a warranty item, it is the focus of the ﬁrst inspection to be performed when the new vehicle is delivered. This is a general check for damage or missing parts. If the vehicle was purchased Freight on Board (FOB) destination, correc

tion of any deﬁciency attributable to the carrier is still the responsibility of the manufacturer, and their appropriate office must be notiﬁed. If the vehicle was purchased fob. origin, then the government deals directly with the carrier. Any damage or missing parts must be noted on the Government Bill of Lading (GBL) before the document is signed. The carrier must be given the opportunity to inspect the vehicle without unrea
sonable delay before the vehicle is repaired. After the vehicle is repaired, the repair invoice amount will be deducted from the carrier’s invoice

when IRS is billed for transportation charges. If the damage appears to be so extensive that the repair cost would exceed the transportation cost or repair of the vehicle seems uneconomical, the property officer or au
thorized representative may refuse to sign for, and refuse delivery of, the vehicle. The receiving office will forward a copy of the receiving report to their local FMSS Motor Vehicle Coordinator.
All personnel involved in acceptance and operation of motor vehicles must comply with the following maintenance and warranty provisions:

comply with the following maintenance and warranty provisions: a. If the vehicle is still within the manufacturer’s warranty period, it must taken to the nearest authorized dealer for the make of vehicle for at no cost to the government. The warranty/guarantee for purchased vehicles is as stated in the GSA contract of purchase for the applicable year. Expenditures for repairs during the warranty period must be to administrative review at all levels b. The IRS must use recycled products when available, as long as they meet manufacturer warranty requirements. These may include motor oil, and recycled antifreeze. c. The vehicle operators must maintain fuel and mileage records and evaluate the cause of any signiﬁcant change in miles per gallon of fuel used by a vehicle Whenever the IRS disposes of a motor vehicle other than by transfer to another federal agency, title is transferred by means of SF-

, Certiﬁcate of Release of a Motor Vehicle. and SF
-A, Agency Record Copy of the United States Government Certiﬁcate of Release of a Motor Vehicle, in connection with the release of government-owned motor vehicles.

If the vehicle is still within the manufacturer’s warranty period, it must taken to the nearest authorized dealer for the make of vehicle for at no cost to the government. The warranty/guarantee for purchased vehicles is as stated in the GSA contract of purchase for the applicable year. Expenditures for repairs during the warranty period must be to administrative review at all levels The IRS must use recycled products when available, as long as they meet manufacturer warranty requirements. These may include motor oil, and recycled antifreeze. The vehicle operators must maintain fuel and mileage records and evaluate the cause of any signiﬁcant change in miles per gallon of fuel used by a vehicle
) Whenever the IRS disposes of a motor vehicle other than by transfer to another federal agency, title is transferred by means of SF-
, Certiﬁcate of Release of a Motor Vehicle. (

) Numbering Series - The Certiﬁcates for Release should be sequentially numbered, using the office code number as a preﬁx, separated by a hyphen, to the series of numbers assigned to avoid duplication. (
) Signing - Employees authorized to dispose of property are authorized to sign SF-
and SF
-A, Agency Record Copy of the United States Government Certiﬁcate of Release of a Motor Vehicle, in connection with the release of government-owned motor vehicles.
